paper_title: Selective Photocatalytic Reduction of CO<sub>2</sub> to CH<sub>4</sub> Modulated by Chloride Modification on Bi<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>6</sub> Nanosheets

catalyst.source: In the present study, a series of chloride-modified Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets were constructed in view of chloride-assisted photocatalytic water oxidation.
catalyst.context: Solar-driven photocatalytic CO 2 reduction into CH 4 with H 2 O is considered to be a promising way to alleviate the energy crisis and greenhouse effect.However, current CO 2 photoreduction technologies tend to overlook the role of photooxidation half reaction as well as the effect of the protons produced by water oxidation on CH 4 generation, resulting in low CO 2 conversion efficiency and poor CH 4 selectivity.In the present study, a series of chloride-modified Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets were constructed in view of chloride-assisted photocatalytic water oxidation.The results show that the CH 4 yield of the synthesized sample can be enhanced up to about 10 times compared to that with no Cl -modification.Besides, the selectivity of CH 4 can be regulated by the loading amount of chloride, varying from 51.29 for Bi 2 WO 6 to 94.98 for the maximum.The increase of product yield is attributed to chloride modification, which not only changed the morphology of the catalyst, but also modified the pathway of water oxidation.Further studies on intermediate products and the density functional theory calculation confirm that the Cl -ions on Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets not only promote H 2 O oxidation, but also lower the energy barrier for intermediate CHO generation, thus facilitating CH 4 production.The results gained herein may provide some illuminating insights into the design of a highly selective photocatalyst for efficient CO 2 reduction.

catalyst.source: For comparison, pure Bi 2 WO 6 and BiOCl were prepared using the same method.
catalyst.context: For comparison, pure Bi 2 WO 6 and BiOCl were prepared using the same method.The Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets were synthesized without adding NaCl, and the product is denoted as BW for brevity.The BiOCl was synthesized without adding Na 2 WO 4 2H 2 O. 2.2.Characterization.Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD; PANalytical X'Pert PRO) was employed to characterize the crystal phases of the catalysts.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM; FEI Tecnai G 2 F20-S-TWIN) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Carl Zeiss Sigma 500) were used to observe the morphology of the synthesized samples.The crystal orientation of the samples was determined by a high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image and a fast-Fourier transform (FFT) diffraction pattern.UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS; Agilent Cary 5000) were obtained to investigate the light-harvesting ability of the catalysts.Raman spectra (Renishaw InVia) were employed to characterize the surface structure of the catalysts.The CO 2 adsorption ability was evaluated by CO 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Quantachrome Autosorb-IQ2) at 0 C and CO 2 temperature programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD; Autosorb-iQ) from 50 to 500 C.The chemical environments of elements on the catalyst's surface were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; PerkinElmer PHI 5300). The intermediate hypochlorite was detected by the spectrophotometry method with the N,N-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine (DPD) reagent as a chromogenic agent (Experimental Section S1.2 in Supporting Information). 2.3.Photocatalytic Performance Tests.The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activities of catalysts were tested in a 200 mL stainlesssteel reactor with a 300 W Xenon lamp (PLS-SXE300, Beijing Perfectlight Co., Ltd.) as the light source.The catalyst powders (20 mg) were dispersed on a glass substrate uniformly and placed into the stainless-steel reactor.Prior to photoreduction CO 2 tests, the reactor was vacuum-treated and scavenged with high purity CO 2 gas (99.995) five times.Then, the compressed high purity CO 2 gas was passed through a water bubbler to generate a mixture of CO 2 and H 2 O vapor.The mixed CO 2 /H 2 O gas was introduced to the stainless steel reactor to act as a reactant. The products from the reactor were detected by gas chromatography (Agilent 7820A).A flame-ionized detector was adopted to determine CH 4 and CO yields, while a thermal conductivity detector was employed to detect the O 2 yield.It should be noted that apart from CO and CH 4 , other products, including H 2 , C 2 H 4 , C 2 H 6 , HCHO, and CH 3 OH, were not detected within the detection limits of our instrument.The 13 C isotope tracing technique was carried out under identical conditions to verify the source of CH 4 and CO.The obtained products were identified by a gas chromatography-mass spectrometer (GC-MS, Agilent 7890B and OmniStar GSD 320). 2.4.Theoretical Calculations.Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the plane-wave technique mentioned in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) code. 32The interactions between ions and valence electrons were described by the projector-augmented wave method. 33The generalized gradient approximation expressed by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was adopted to handle the exchange correlations between electrons. 34,35The detailed computational parameters are shown in Supporting Information.The equilibrium lattice constants of an orthogonal Bi 2 WO 6 unit cell were optimized, when using a 6 6 2 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid for Brillouin zone sampling.We then use it to construct an O-Bi-O terminated Bi 2 WO 6 (001) surface model with p (2 1) periodicity in the x and y directions and one stoichiometric layer in the z direction with a vacuum layer of 15 A in depth in order to separate the surface slab from its periodic duplicates.The detailed computational parameters are shown in Supporting Information.

catalyst.source: A series of chloride-modified Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets are rationally constructed by taking into account the roles of chlorideassisted photocatalytic oxidation.
catalyst.context: A series of chloride-modified Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets are rationally constructed by taking into account the roles of chlorideassisted photocatalytic oxidation.The chloride-modified photocatalysts exhibit excellent CO 2 reduction activity and high CH 4 selectivity than pure Bi 2 WO 6 .The optimal chloridemodified Bi 2 WO 6 achieves a 4.97 mol/g-cat CH 4 yield with 94.98 selectivity after a 3 h illumination.More importantly, cyclic experimental results show that CO 2 reduction activity of the catalyst can be reactivated repeatedly when the catalyst is simply treated with NaCl solution.A CO 2 reduction mechanism involving chloride is thus proposed and further testified by detection of HClO and O 2 .In the presence of chlorides, the photooxidation water half reaction is greatly promoted via the mediating effect of Cl -ions.Simultaneously, the produced protons facilitate the formation of methane, thus resulting in enhanced CH 4 selectivity.DFT calculations further confirm that the presence of Cl -ions on Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets is capable of lowering the energy barrier for intermediate CHO Figure 1.(a) XRD patterns of BW and BW-Clx (x 1-5); (b) Raman spectra of BW, BW-Cl3, and BW-Cl5. Figure 2. (a) TEM image of BW-Cl3 (inset: schematic illustration of Bi 2 WO 6 crystal orientation and the image of vertically standing nanosheets); (b) HRTEM image of BW-Cl3 of the selected area (inset: corresponding FFT pattern). Optical Properties and Band Structure. Figure 4 shows the results of UV-vis DRS for BW and BW-Clx.All the absorption edges of BW and BW-Clx are at around 450 nm. Figure 3. High-resolution XPS spectra of Cl 2p (a) and O 1s (b) for BW, BW-Cl3, and BW-Cl5. Figure 4. (a) UV-vis DRS of BW and BW-Clx; (b) diagram of the energy band structure of BW, BW-Cl3, and BW-Cl5. Figure 5. CO 2 adsorption isotherms of BW, BW-Cl3, and BW-Cl5. Figure 6.Yields (a) and selectivity (b) of CO and CH 4 for BW, BiOCl, and BW-Clx (x 1-5) for 3 h; (c) yields of CO and CH 4 under various conditions for 3 h; and (d) GC-MS analyses for CO and CH 4 produced with 13 CO 2 as feed gas. Figure 7. (a) Cyclic photocatalytic activity of BW-Cl3 and BW-Cl3 reactivated with NaCl solution; (b) yields of products for BW, HNO 3 -treated BW-Cl3, and BW-Cl3. Figure 8. Schematic illustration of the possible CO 2 reduction mechanism. Figure 9. Absorption spectra in the DPD test for BW-Cl3 before and after photoirradiation for 1 h. co-catalyst.source: In the present study, a series of chloride-modified Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets were constructed in view of chloride-assisted photocatalytic water oxidation.
co-catalyst.context: Solar-driven photocatalytic CO 2 reduction into CH 4 with H 2 O is considered to be a promising way to alleviate the energy crisis and greenhouse effect.However, current CO 2 photoreduction technologies tend to overlook the role of photooxidation half reaction as well as the effect of the protons produced by water oxidation on CH 4 generation, resulting in low CO 2 conversion efficiency and poor CH 4 selectivity.In the present study, a series of chloride-modified Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets were constructed in view of chloride-assisted photocatalytic water oxidation.The results show that the CH 4 yield of the synthesized sample can be enhanced up to about 10 times compared to that with no Cl -modification.Besides, the selectivity of CH 4 can be regulated by the loading amount of chloride, varying from 51.29 for Bi 2 WO 6 to 94.98 for the maximum.The increase of product yield is attributed to chloride modification, which not only changed the morphology of the catalyst, but also modified the pathway of water oxidation.Further studies on intermediate products and the density functional theory calculation confirm that the Cl -ions on Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets not only promote H 2 O oxidation, but also lower the energy barrier for intermediate CHO generation, thus facilitating CH 4 production.The results gained herein may provide some illuminating insights into the design of a highly selective photocatalyst for efficient CO 2 reduction.

light source.source: The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activities of catalysts were tested in a 200 mL stainlesssteel reactor with a 300 W Xenon lamp (PLS-SXE300, Beijing Perfectlight Co., Ltd.) as the light source.
light source.context: For comparison, pure Bi 2 WO 6 and BiOCl were prepared using the same method.The Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets were synthesized without adding NaCl, and the product is denoted as BW for brevity.The BiOCl was synthesized without adding Na 2 WO 4 2H 2 O. 2.2.Characterization.Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD; PANalytical X'Pert PRO) was employed to characterize the crystal phases of the catalysts.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM; FEI Tecnai G 2 F20-S-TWIN) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Carl Zeiss Sigma 500) were used to observe the morphology of the synthesized samples.The crystal orientation of the samples was determined by a high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image and a fast-Fourier transform (FFT) diffraction pattern.UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS; Agilent Cary 5000) were obtained to investigate the light-harvesting ability of the catalysts.Raman spectra (Renishaw InVia) were employed to characterize the surface structure of the catalysts.The CO 2 adsorption ability was evaluated by CO 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Quantachrome Autosorb-IQ2) at 0 C and CO 2 temperature programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD; Autosorb-iQ) from 50 to 500 C.The chemical environments of elements on the catalyst's surface were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; PerkinElmer PHI 5300). The intermediate hypochlorite was detected by the spectrophotometry method with the N,N-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine (DPD) reagent as a chromogenic agent (Experimental Section S1.2 in Supporting Information). 2.3.Photocatalytic Performance Tests.The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activities of catalysts were tested in a 200 mL stainlesssteel reactor with a 300 W Xenon lamp (PLS-SXE300, Beijing Perfectlight Co., Ltd.) as the light source.The catalyst powders (20 mg) were dispersed on a glass substrate uniformly and placed into the stainless-steel reactor.Prior to photoreduction CO 2 tests, the reactor was vacuum-treated and scavenged with high purity CO 2 gas (99.995) five times.Then, the compressed high purity CO 2 gas was passed through a water bubbler to generate a mixture of CO 2 and H 2 O vapor.The mixed CO 2 /H 2 O gas was introduced to the stainless steel reactor to act as a reactant. The products from the reactor were detected by gas chromatography (Agilent 7820A).A flame-ionized detector was adopted to determine CH 4 and CO yields, while a thermal conductivity detector was employed to detect the O 2 yield.It should be noted that apart from CO and CH 4 , other products, including H 2 , C 2 H 4 , C 2 H 6 , HCHO, and CH 3 OH, were not detected within the detection limits of our instrument.The 13 C isotope tracing technique was carried out under identical conditions to verify the source of CH 4 and CO.The obtained products were identified by a gas chromatography-mass spectrometer (GC-MS, Agilent 7890B and OmniStar GSD 320). 2.4.Theoretical Calculations.Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the plane-wave technique mentioned in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) code. 32The interactions between ions and valence electrons were described by the projector-augmented wave method. 33The generalized gradient approximation expressed by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was adopted to handle the exchange correlations between electrons. 34,35The detailed computational parameters are shown in Supporting Information.The equilibrium lattice constants of an orthogonal Bi 2 WO 6 unit cell were optimized, when using a 6 6 2 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid for Brillouin zone sampling.We then use it to construct an O-Bi-O terminated Bi 2 WO 6 (001) surface model with p (2 1) periodicity in the x and y directions and one stoichiometric layer in the z direction with a vacuum layer of 15 A in depth in order to separate the surface slab from its periodic duplicates.The detailed computational parameters are shown in Supporting Information.
